full_text: Saddened to learn of the passing of Prof. Anani Dzidzienyo. His smile always lit up a room as did his warmth and kindness. RIP great man. ‚ù§Ô∏è@BrownUniversity #AfricanaStudies

One of my favorite professors at @BrownUniversity has gone home to the ancestors. Anani Dzidzienyo was a beautiful man, an incredible scholar and he had the most engaging and infectious laugh. A huge influence on my understanding of race and also what it means to be an educator.

Prof. Dzidzienyo was a leading scholar of Afro-Latin American politics and history, specifically on Afro-Brazilians. He taught @BrownUniversity from 1973 to the present. As a founding member of the @africanaatbrown, Prof. Dzidzienyo became the program's second director in 1986.
Wow! Professor Anani Dzidzienyo has joined the ancestors. What a great loss! Prof. Dzidzienyo, a Ghanaian scholar, pioneered the study of African Diaspora Studies @BrownUniversity in the early 1970s.
@profdanhicks @BrownUniversity @RISDMuseum Though now that I think about @RISDMuseum whatever happened to the ‚ÄúBenin Head‚Äù? Still on display? Or on its way to Nigeria?

@profdanhicks Yeah I‚Äôm the US the anthropology museum @BrownUniversity has a few items. The @RISDMuseum does too. Thankfully there has been a growing push to speak publicly about these items, and in RISD‚Äôs case begin working on restitution.
